unnormalised: The Maths teacher, Mr. Sharma, always started his class with a story. Today, it was about geometry and trigonometry, topics that usually made half the class groan. He began, "Imagine, if you will, a perfectly symmetrical rangoli being created for Diwali, each angle precisely measured." He paused for effect, a twinkle in his eye.
normalised: The Maths teacher, Mister Sharma, always started his class with a story. Today, it was about geometry and trigonometry, topics that usually made half the class groan. He began, "Imagine, if you will, a perfectly symmetrical rangoli being created for Diwali, each angle precisely measured." He paused for effect, a twinkle in his eye.

unnormalised: He continued, "In Jaipur, during Jantar Mantar's construction back in 1734 AD, Maharaja Jai Singh II meticulously calculated angles using massive sundials. Ever wondered how they got that level of accuracy? Trigonometry, my friends! Think about it - a sundial relies on the angle of the sun (θ) to tell time, and that angle changes throughout the day. You can use trigonometric functions like sin(θ), cos(θ), and tan(θ) to calculate the sun's altitude and azimuth at any given time!" He emphasized 'tan(θ) = opposite/adjacent' with a flourish.
normalised: He continued, "In Jaipur, during Jantar Mantar's construction back in one thousand seven hundred and thirty four A-D, Maharaja Jai Singh the Second meticulously calculated angles using massive sundials. Ever wondered how they got that level of accuracy? Trigonometry, my friends! Think about it - a sundial relies on the angle of the sun (theta) to tell time, and that angle changes throughout the day. You can use trigonometric functions like sine of theta, cosine of theta, and tangent of theta to calculate the sun's altitude and azimuth at any given time!" He emphasized 'tangent of theta equals opposite divided by adjacent' with a flourish.

unnormalised: Mr. Sharma then moved on to geometry. He recalled a visit to the Taj Mahal. "The Taj, that magnificent testament to love, is a symphony of geometric shapes. Look at the arches, the domes, the minarets – all based on fundamental geometric principles. The golden ratio, approx. 1.618, is supposed to be present in its design, a testament to harmonic proportions." He scribbled some equations on the board, 'Area of circle = πr^2' and 'Volume of sphere = 4/3πr^3.'

He scribbled some equations on the board, 'Area of circle equals pi r squared' and 'Volume of sphere equals four divided by three pi r cubed.'

unnormalised: "Even something as simple as calculating the area of your bedroom floor involves geometry. Let's say your room is 12 ft by 15 ft. The area is simply 12 x 15 = 180 sq ft. Knowing this helps you figure out how much carpet to buy, or how many tiles you need. Think about designing your dream house, all those elevations and blueprints require solid understanding of geometry." He paused to sip some water.

unnormalised: He then challenged the class, “Imagine you are planning a cricket match, figuring out the distance between the wickets, approximately 22 yards, using angles and bearings to ensure a fair game. Or calculate the height of a building using triangulation with a clinometer; that's practical application!" He even connected to the movie "3 Idiots", when Raju asked his interviewer, what is the area of this pen nib. "Remember kids", Mr. Sharma warned, "Geometry and Trigonometry is not just about formulas, it is about understanding how the world works around us."

Mr. Sharma smiled, collecting his notes. Maybe, just maybe, a few rangolis would be a little more mathematically precise this Diwali. He also told them to memorise the value of 'π=3.14159' for the next class, else there would be consequences.
